notes:
1. Mass vs. Weight

  • Mass (m): A measure of the amount of matter in an object. It is a scalar quantity and is constant regardless of location. SI unit: kg. US unit: slug (or lb-mass).
  • Weight (W): The gravitational force acting on an object. It is a vector pointing towards the center of the Earth. Weight depends on the local acceleration due to gravity ($g$). SI unit: Newton (N). US unit: lb-force.
$$ W = mg $$

Standard gravity $g \approx 9.81 \text{ m/s}^2 \approx 32.2 \text{ ft/s}^2$.

2. Density and Specific Weight

  • Density ($\rho$): Mass per unit volume. $\rho = m/V$. Units: kg/m³, slug/ft³.
  • Specific Weight ($\gamma$): Weight per unit volume. $\gamma = W/V = \rho g$. Units: N/m³, lb/ft³.
  • Specific Gravity (SG): Ratio of the density of a substance to the density of water. Dimensionless. $\rho_{substance} = SG \times \rho_{water}$.

3. Calculating Total Weight

For a homogeneous body of volume $V$, total weight is $W = \gamma V$. For composite bodies, sum the weights of individual parts: $W_{total} = \sum W_i$.
